title: 111_hr1956
content: The Act may be cited as the "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act". It allows for the offset of state judicial debts against income tax refunds. The "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" allows for the offset of state judicial debts against income tax refunds through an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Upon notice from a State judicial branch or agency, the Secretary of the Treasury can reduce overpayments to pay off past-due State judicial debts. The Secretary of the Treasury can reduce overpayments to pay off past-due State judicial debts by notifying the State judicial branch or agency of the person's details and reducing the overpayment amount. If an offset is made on a joint return, the notice must include the details of each filer. Overpayments are reduced after liabilities for internal revenue tax and past-due support are addressed. The Secretary of the Treasury can reduce overpayments by applying them to past-due debts owed to State agencies or judicial branches. If multiple debts are owed to a State agency or judicial branch, the overpayment will be used to offset those debts. The Secretary of the Treasury can reduce overpayments by applying them to past-due debts owed to State agencies or judicial branches, in the order they accrued. Rules similar to subsection (e)(4) apply for debt consideration. A past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debt is defined as a debt resulting from a court judgment in criminal or traffic cases, assessed and past-due. The Secretary can reduce overpayments by applying them to past-due State judicial debts, including court costs, fines, and restitution to crime victims. Regulations will specify the submission of notices and necessary information for debt reduction procedures. The regulations allow for the reduction of overpayments by applying them to State judicial debts. State judicial branches and agencies may be required to pay a fee to reimburse the Secretary for the cost of the reduction procedure. Any erroneous payments made to a State judicial branch or agency must be promptly repaid to the Secretary. The regulations permit the reduction of overpayments by applying them to State judicial debts. State judicial branches or agencies may need to pay a fee to reimburse the Secretary for the reduction process. Erroneous payments to a State judicial branch or agency must be promptly repaid to the Secretary. Amendments are made to sections 6103(l)(10), 6402(a), 6402(d)(2), and 6402(e)(3)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this Act apply to State judicial debts and future Federal tax liabilities. The Act's amendments now include refunds for taxable years starting after December 31, 2008, with the addition of section (g).
